interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

effects: Euphoria, Dry Mouth, Mood lift, Itchiness, Relaxant, Constipation, Pupil constriction, Analgesia.
drugs.summary: Codeine is a weaker opioid used to treat mild to moderate pain and to relieve cough. In many countries it is available over the counter in combination with paracetamol, which can easily be extracted to retrieve near-pure codeine. For this reason, it is used widely as a recreational opioid. It is metabolised into morphine in the body at a rate of 5% mg for mg.
drugs.name: Codeine

drugs.summary: A nootropic drug of the racetam class, originally developed to treat Alzheimer's disease, it is currently being investigated as a treatment for major depressive disorder and generalised anxiety disorder. May be a modulator of the AMPA receptor. Limited recreational value.

drugs.summary: Alkaloid found in Tabernanthe iboga and related species. Persistently reduces the self-administration of Cocaine and Morphine in rats.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

drugs.summary: Empathogen with strong stimulant effects, very loosely related to benzylpiperidine.
drugs.name: Cyclo-Methiodrone

drugs.summary: Muscle relaxant and CNS depressant used to relieve skeletal muscle spasms and associated pain in acute musculoskeletal conditions. Sometimes prescribed off-label for treatment of fibromyalgia or as a sleep aid. Has little recreational value alone, but may potentiate some opioids. May cause drowsiness, dry mouth and dizziness.
drugs.name: Cyclobenzaprine

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

interactions.details: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.name: D2PM

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: Psychedelic drug of the tryptamine class.
drugs.name: DALT

effects: surreal interactions with world, hallucinations, dry mouth, nausea, fear, anxiety, amnesia, difficulty breathing, confusion, delirium
drugs.summary: A family of plants containing various Tropane alkaloids. Produces long-lasting deliriant effects including very realistic and often unpleasant hallucinations along with short-term amnesia. Datura plants are toxic to humans, and potency varies greatly from plant-to-plant, making the drug extremely difficult to dose safely. Not typically regarded as recreational.
drugs.name: Datura

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A surprisingly uncommon analogue of DMT with similar effects and reported oral activity without the aid of an MAOI.
drugs.name: DET

interactions.name: Î±MT
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: A highly abusable stimulant. It is rarely prescribed in the US to treat ADHD, and is very similar in effects to Adderall, as its main ingredient is 75% of what adderall is.
drugs.name: Dexedrine

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

drugs.summary: An opioid analgesic that is an optical isomer of levopropoxyphene. Used to treat mild pain and often used for its antitussive properties. It has been taken off the market in Europe and US due to concerns of health issues relating to the Kidney, Liver, Heart and Respiratory Disorders. Just a bit stronger than Tramadol.
drugs.name: Dextropropoxyphene

drugs.summary: A very common and widely prescribed benzodiazepine with hypnotic and sedative qualities. The metre by which other benzodiazepines are compared. May cause amnesia and lowered inhibitions in excess. Has a relatively long half-life in comparison with other benzodiazepines.

drugs.summary: A benzodiazepine drug and analogue of diazepam first synthesised by Leo Sternbach at Hoffman-LaRoche in 1960, it has become prominent as an RC benzodiazepine on the grey market in recent years, particularly with the decline in etizolam availability. drugs.summary: An industrial solvent which is sometimes used recreationally as a dissociative anaesthetic, with a short length of action. Effects are similar to alcohol. Leaves one's breath tasting and smelling strongly of ether for much longer than the experience lasts.

The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

effects: Euphoria, Dry Mouth, Mood lift, Itchiness, Relaxant, Constipation, Pupil constriction, Analgesia.
drugs.summary: A powerful opioid of equivalent strength to morphine, rarely seen outside of medical environments. Often used to treat severe pain where morphine is contraindicated. Usually found in combination with the antihistamine Cyclizine, which potentiates it.
drugs.name: Dipipanone

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A rare tryptamine psychedelic closely related to DMT, with the interesting property of having little visual hallucinations, but strong auditory effects.
drugs.name: DiPT

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: Also known as methylhexanamine, this sympathetomimetic drug was developed as a nasal decongestant by Eli Lilly in the 1940s. It has been used as a weight loss aid and missold as a dietary supplement and component of some energy drinks. Carries a risk of heart attack, stroke and other life-threatening cardiovascular issues.

interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are  reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also  allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk.

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions.

effects: visual distortions, a 'stoned' feeling, sense of well being.
drugs.summary: The most popular psychedelic amphetamine due to its pleasant effects, lower potency and shorter duration. Effects have been described as 'sillier' than LSD and related DOX chemicals
drugs.name: DOM

interactions.name: Î±MT
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The 5-MeO class of tryptamines can be unpredictable in their interactions, particularly increasing the risk of unpleasant physical side effects.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: As an NMDA antagonist MXE potentiates DOx which can be unpleasantly intense

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can be uncomfortable. Coming down on the MDMA while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating it may cause some physical discomfort.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: The DOx class as psychedelic stimulants have the potential to mask the effects of DXM and could lead to redosing to an unsafe level. DXM can also potentiate DOx resulting in an unpleasantly intense experience.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of cocaine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from cocaine while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A very rare psychedelic Amphetamine. That is more rough on the body then other DOx compounds. Making it physically painful in some cases.
drugs.name: DON

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A rare psychedelic amphetamine of the same class as DOM. This is a powerful and potent psychedelic with all the effects you would expect from an amphetamine. Described by Shulgin as a 'heavy duty psychedelic'. Analogue of 2C-P.
drugs.name: DOPR

drugs.summary: A first generation antihistamine and anticholinergic, originally used to treat nausea and itching, and later as a sleep aid. Causes drowsiness, and delirium in overdose. Sometimes used with opioids to combat nausea and potentiate effects.
drugs.name: Doxylamine

effects: Delirium, dream-like experiences, paranoia, visual and audio distortions, dry mouth, muscle cramps, nausea, dysphoria, tremors. Often described as a pretty negative experience.
drugs.summary: An antihistamine which, when taken in smaller doses relieves allergies and insomnia. In larger doses works as a deliriant and can actually keep the user awake. Generally the 'high' of this drug is reported as dysphoric, potentially causing hallucinations indistinguishable from reality.
drugs.name: DPH

effects: A psychedelic tryptamine with "a wide range of effects at any particular dose depending on the individual"
drugs.summary: N,N-Dipropyltryptamine, a psychedelic tryptamine compound and lesser-known analogue of DMT, with similar psychedelic effects. Like DMT it is a partial serotonin receptor agonist.
drugs.name: DPT

effects: Delirium, Dream-Like-Experiences, Paranoia, Visual and audio distortions, dry mouth, muscle cramps, Nausea, Dysphoria, Tremors.
drugs.summary: A combination of diphenhydramine and a mild stimulant to counteract the drowsiness accompanied by typical medical use of diphenhydramine. Roughly half the potency of DPH. Small doses can relieve motion sickness, reduce body load from opioids or DXM. Becomes a deliriant in high doses, keeping the user awake and often causing dysphoric, realistic hallucinations.
drugs.name: Dimenhydrinate

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Additionally CNS depression can lead to difficulty breathing. Avoid on anything higher than 1st plateau.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the patient falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position. This combination is hard to predict

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.details: High risk of serotonin syndrome

interactions.details: High risk of serotonin syndrome.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The DOx class as psychedelic stimulants have the potential to mask the effects of DXM and could lead to redosing to an unsafe level. DXM can also potentiate DOx resulting in an unpleasantly intense experience.

interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: Ephedrine is a sympathomimetic amine commonly used as a stimulant, concentration aid, decongestant, appetite suppressant, and to treat hypotension associated with anaesthesia. A methamphetamine analogue and commonly used in the production of methamphetamine.
drugs.name: Ephedrine

drugs.summary: A dissociative drug which is less potent and less confusing than MXE but with otherwise similar properties. Reported as causing light stimulant effects at lower doses.
drugs.name: Ephenidine

drugs.summary: Ethylpropyltryptamine a novel tryptamine, that is the structural homologue of DMT.
drugs.name: EPT

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: First synthesised in the 50s, this uncommon drug was reexamined by David Nichols in the 1990s. It is an analogue of mescaline which is roughly six times more potent, and is thus a powerful psychedelic phenethylamine. Subjective effects may include stimulation and hallucinations.
drugs.name: Escaline

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. Vomit aspiration a risk when passed out, lay down in recovery position if ingested.

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: A rarely prescribed medium-duration prescription benzodiazepine. Mainly used as a hypnotic, it can cause amnesia and lowered inhibitions in excess.
drugs.name: Estazolam

effects: anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, amnesia, dystaxia, hypnotic
drugs.summary: The d-isomer of Zopiclone, this drug is a potent hypnotic 'Z' drug often used to treat insomnia. High doses may cause amnesia, delirium and lowered inhibitions. Should not be combined with any depressants. Limited recreational value.
drugs.name: Eszopiclone

drugs.summary: A psychedelic drug and slightly more potent analogue of LSD, first synthesised by Alexander Shulgin - sometimes described as being less 'abrasive' than LSD. Less common than the associated AL-LAD, though has seen some popularity since its release on the Internet research chemical scene in 2015.
drugs.name: ETH-LAD

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: Analogue of Methaqualone that was mostly marketed in France. Slightly weaker and shorter acting than the prior.
drugs.name: Ethaqualone

drugs.summary: Ethketamine is a research chemical with properties similar to ketamine. While ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic producing hallucinogenic and sedative effects, recreational users have reported euphoria and dissociation when using NENK.
drugs.name: Ethketamine

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: Ethylcathinone is a synthetic stimulant. It is similar to ecstasy in the sense that it provides euphoria, feelings of empathy and openness, and a desire to talk with others. It also carries over to some of the negative effects of ecstasy, such as insomnia, tightened jaw muscles, and grinding of the teeth.
drugs.name: Ethylcathinone

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

effects: Euphoria, Dry Mouth, Mood lift, Itchiness, Relaxant, Constipation, Pupil constriction, Analgesia.
drugs.summary: A medium-strength opioid analgesic and analogue of morphine. Considered less potent than morphine but more potent than codeine, and has been used in Germany for this reason. Said to have a 'ceiling' effect where no more euphoria occurs with increased dosage. Under investigation as a maintainance drug in opioid dependence therapy.

drugs.summary: Potent psychostimulant, similar to Methylphenidate. Note: Ethylphenidate should NOT be insufflated as it is known to be highly caustic and will cause serious harm to your nasal septum, even with light usage.
drugs.name: Ethylphenidate

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

effects: anxiolytic, hypnotic, sedative, muscle relaxant, amnesia, dystaxia
drugs.summary: A thienodiazepine anxiolytic. Similar in action to benzodiazepine drugs. Relieves anxiety, causes sedation and mild euphoria. High doses can lead to losing memory of what happened while on the drug. Users often compulsively re-dose frequently leading to accidental blackouts. Can be found in pressed pharmaceutical pills from various countries, clandestine pill presses, or as a powder
drugs.name: Etizolam

drugs.summary: A substance in the racetam family. Appears to be a GABA(B) agonist, and has shown to block memory disruptions caused by Baclofen, another GABA(B) Agonist. Similar to another compound in the racetam family Coluracetam, it enhances High affinity choline reuptake (HACU). Also research is conducted if it helps with ADHD and Congitive impairment.
drugs.name: Fasoracetam

effects: Analgesia, euphoria, feelings of relaxation, sedative effects, changes in focus, attention, respiratory depression, nausea, constipation, dry mouth, somnolence, confusion, weakness, sweating, fatigue, dizziness, anxiety
drugs.summary: Fentanyl is a synthetic opiate analgesic with a rapid onset and short duration of action. It is a strong agonist at the Î¼-opioid receptors and is historically used to treat breakthrough pain. Fentanyl is approximately 100 times more potent than Morphine, and is commonly used as a patch. Sometimes used as an adulterant for heroin, which has led to many overdose deaths.
drugs.name: Fentanyl

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: A somewhat common benzodiazepine drug known for its extreme duration, with effects for larger doses reaching up to three days. Sedative, hypnotic and anxiolytic, this compound is an analogue of Phenazepam. First discovered in the 1960s, it was never marketed as a licit drug, but has recently become available as an RC. Not to be confused with Flubromazolam.
drugs.name: Flubromazepam

drugs.summary: A very potent benzodiazepine derivative that is related to Triazolam and Pyrazolam. Popular in the research chemical scene, it is a potent sedative, hypnotic and anxiolytic. Potential for amnesia and reduced inhibitions in higher dose. Not to be confused with Flubromazepam, which is much less potent and has a much longer half-life.
drugs.name: Flubromazolam

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: Known as Rohypnol or 'roofies,' this infamous drug has similar qualities to most other benzodiazepines; sedating with strong hypnotic effects. Despite being known as a 'date rape drug' has only been implicated in a small number of such crimes. Danger of respiratory depression in combination with other depressants. May cause amnesia and lowered inhibitions in overdose.
drugs.name: Flunitrazepam

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Blackouts.
drugs.summary: A very potent hypnotic Benzodiazepine. Triazolo version of Flunitrazepam.
drugs.name: Flunitrazolam

drugs.summary: A dissociative anaesthetic also known as 2-FPPP, very little is known about this obscure and rare drug. Reported by some to be stimulating, having effects similar to other dissociative drugs such as PCP and ketamine.
drugs.name: Fluorolintane

drugs.summary: An anxiolytic analogue of GABA and Phenibut, with similar activity to the latter. Expected to be 5-10 times as potent as phenibut, some preliminary reports suggest tolerance builds more slowly.
drugs.name: Fluorophenibut

drugs.summary: A benzodiazepine derivative. It was invented in Japan, and has mainly stayed in that area. Similar potency to Diazepam, yet produces a more marked sedation and impaired coordination. interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: The psychoactive isomer of methylphenidate, mostly used to treat ADHD. Twice as potent as methylphenidate, and is said to have cleaner psychostimulant effects with fewer side effects.
drugs.name: Dexmethylphenidate

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: An analogue of GABA also known as Neurontin, originally developed to treat epilepsy. Commonly prescribed for neuropathic pain, it also has pronounced anxiolytic effects leading to its use in treating anxiety disorders.
drugs.name: Gabapentin

effects: relaxation, mood lift, happiness, sociability, increased sex drive, lowered inhibitions, analgesia, dystaxia, drowsiness, sleep, amnesia
drugs.summary: A pro-drug to GHB whose rapid absorption leads it to have a faster onset and shorter duration. Used in a similar manner to GHB, as a less-toxic alternative to alcohol. Consume slowly instead of as a "shot" to hugely improve safety and reduce overdose risk.
drugs.name: GBL

effects: Similar to alcohol, but subjectively 'cleaner'
drugs.summary: A euphoric depressant which is prescribed as a sleep aid and sometimes to help with Alcohol detox. Also used as a recreational depressant, as a non-toxic alternative to Alcohol. Despite not having Alcohol's toxicity it is risky due to among other things inconsistent concentration in commonly sold solution form, and can be very dangerous if taken with other depressants.
drugs.name: GHB

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: Most likely a TRI, such as HDMP-28, short history of human use.
drugs.name: HDEP-28

interactions.name: Î±MT
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: Also commonly known as methylnapthidate. A functional stimulant similar to methylphenidate but with a longer duration. Not especially recreational.
drugs.name: HDMP-28

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.
