effects: Euphoria, Dry Mouth, Mood lift, Itchiness, Relaxant, Constipation, Pupil Constriction, Analgesia.
drugs.summary: A powerful opioid derived from Morphine, with 2-4x its potency. Infamous for a high addiction potential and fatal respiratory depression in overdose, C. R. Alder Wright first synthesised this compound in 1874 trying to find a less addictive alternative to Morphine. In recent years, it has often been sold cut with the extremely potent fentanyl, causing a spike in overdose deaths.

drugs.summary: A cathinone based stimulant. Hexen (aka Ethyl-Hexedrone) acts as an NDRI to produce it's effects, and as with most cathinones has a fast onset and short duration. This drug has very little history of human consumption and next to no research/data, and therefor should be treated with caution as a research chemical.
drugs.name: Hexen

drugs.summary: A codeine-derived opioid generally unheard of outside the United States. Generally mild in effects, used as an analgesic and cough-supressant. Sometimes used recreationally.
drugs.name: Hydrocodone

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.details: No expected interactions, some opioids have serotonin action, and could lead to Serotonin Syndrome or a seizure. These are pretty much only to Pentazocine, Methadone, Tramadol, Tapenatdol.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT

interactions.name: Caffeine

effects: Euphoria, Dry Mouth, Mood lift, Itchiness, Relaxant, Constipation, Pupil Constriction, Analgesia.
drugs.summary: An opioid that is roughly 5x the potency of IV Morphine. Only comes in IR tablets in the US, and is given mostly as XR in other countries. It is frequently used in hospitals for short, but immediate pain relief during procedures requiring the patient to be awake. Also frequently used as a recreational opiate.
drugs.name: Hydromorphone

drugs.summary: An antihistamine drug commonly prescribed for anxiety, itchiness, nausea, and insomnia. Hydroxyzine has also been used to potentiate the analgesia of opioids as well as diminishing the negative effects of opioids, such as itchiness.
drugs.name: Hydroxyzine

effects: Addiction help, Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil constriction, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: An alkaloid found in many African plants most famously Iboga, with psychedelic and hallucinogenic properties. May be unpleasant. Traditionally used in tribal environments for coming-of-age rituals, it has recently been used as an alternative treatment for drug addiction although this usage has not been backed by conclusive data in humans. Has killed in overdose.
drugs.name: Ibogaine

drugs.summary: A ubiquitously available pain reliever/fever reducer. Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, available in many forms. It is sometimes used to reduce the body-load caused by certain drugs, such as stimulants.
drugs.name: Ibuprofen

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: 5-MEO-TMT, one of Shulgin's lesser known creations. A psychedelic tryptamine little heard of outside of TiHKaL with very little known information about its effects on humans. May be particularly given to causing nausea.
drugs.name: Indapex

interactions.name: Î±MT
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: Indane analogue of Pyrophenidone, a NDRI stimulant with a short duration.
drugs.name: Indapyrophenidone

drugs.summary: IPPH (or incorrectly IPH) is a novel piperidine based methylphenidate analogue and NDRI stimulant, but comes with much less physical side effects.
drugs.name: Isopropylphenidate

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A analogue of mescaline, and more closely related to proscaline.
drugs.name: Isoproscaline

drugs.summary: A hoax which began in online communities of a non-existent drug which was claimed to result from a process involving human waste. http://www.snopes.com/crime/warnings/jenkem.asp
drugs.name: Jenkem

drugs.summary: A South African plant containing numerous psychoactive alkaloids, including mesembrine and mesembrenone. The first written account of the substance was in 1662. The pharmacology of these compounds is poorly understood, but they are suspected to be serotonin uptake inhibitors and potentially monoamine releasers. Said to suppress appetite, produce mild euphoria and reduce anxiety.
drugs.name: Kanna

drugs.summary: Tropical evergreen shrub with large heart-shaped leaves and woody stems. Its thick roots are mashed or ground and made into a cold and bitter-tasting beverage used similarly to alcohol. It has a long history of ritual and recreational use in Pacific Polynesia and is now a common herbal product, used widely by those in certain societies as part of a 'Kava Culture.'
drugs.name: Kava

effects: A feeling of drunkenness and well being at low doses. As dose increases the user may begin to feel a disconnection from their body. At 'khole' doses the user may become completely disconnected from both body and mind.
drugs.summary: A short acting dissociative anaesthetic and hallucinogen commonly used in emergency medicine. It is the prototypical dissociative, and is widely used at sub-anesthetic doses recreationally. Small doses are comparable with alcohol, while larger doses are immobilising and lead to psychedelic experiences: the "K-Hole."
drugs.name: Ketamine

drugs.summary: Benzodiazepine derivative that has most of the common benzodiazepine effects. Has been seen to have similar effectiveness when compared to Diazepam, with milder side-effects. Is marketed in few countries.
drugs.name: Ketazolam

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

effects: Euphoria, Dry Mouth, Mood lift, Itchiness, Relaxant, Constipation, Pupil constriction, Analgesia.
drugs.summary: An opioid analgesic drug that also acts as an NDMA antagonist. Found to be as potent as morphine in physical side effects, and has high potential for addiction like all opioids do. Overdose may lead to respiratory depression/death. Do not mix with CNS depressants or stimulants. Caution should be used for asthmatic users.
drugs.name: Ketobemidone

interactions.details: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: A drug made out of the leaves of Mitragyna Speciosa, which is related to coffee. Stimulating at lower doses, with opioid effects at higher doses. Frequent heavy use can cause physical addiction and withdrawals.
drugs.name: Kratom

drugs.summary: An Amino acid that is structural similar to Glutamine. Most report it as a relaxing agent without much sedation. Most commonly found tea. Usually mixed with Caffeine.

effects: visual distortions, a sense of childlike wonder, brightening of colors,racing thoughts, hue shifts, euphoria, anxiety, confusion
drugs.summary: LSD is a popular psychedelic with a relatively long history of use and research, and as such is known to be relatively safe despite its extremely high potency. It is the archetypical psychedelic to which all others are compared, and remains in popular usage.
drugs.name: LSD

drugs.summary: Psychedelic of the lysergamide class, less potent by weight and produces a rather mild, dreamy and even sedating trip compared to its bigger brother LSD.
drugs.name: LSM-775

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A lysergamide very similar to LSD usually distinguishable only by its shorter duration, though some subjective reports have noted it may be slightly more introspective and slightly less confusing.
drugs.name: LSZ

drugs.summary: Synthetically created Î9-THC, the main psychoactive ingredient in cannabis.
drugs.name: Marinol

interactions.name: Î±MT
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: Mushrooms
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: LSD
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: DMT
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Mescaline
interactions.details: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: A rare entactogenic drug and analogue of MDMA possibly first synthesised by David Nichols. Potentially less potent than related drugs of its type. Sometimes referred to as a 'watered down MDMA.'
drugs.name: MBDB

The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: A quite rare empathogen closely related to MDMA. Yet is less potent than the prior.
drugs.name: MDEA

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Tramadol

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of  phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with MDMA will lead to hypertensive crises.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can be uncomfortable. Coming down on the MDMA while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: Some of the 5-MeO tryptamines are a bit unpredictable and should be mixed with MDMA with care

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: There have been reports of risky serotonergic interactions when the two are taken at the same time, but MXE taken to the end of an MDMA experience does not appear to cause the same issues.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Cocaine blocks some of the desirable effects of MDMA while increasing the risk of heart attack.

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: Caffiene is not really necessary with MDMA and increases any neurotoxic effects from MDMA

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both MDMA and alcohol cause dehydration. Approach this combination with caution, moderation and sufficient hydration. More than a small amount of alcohol will dull the euphoria of MDMA

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Large amounts of GHB/GBL may overwhelm the effects of MDMA on the comedown.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Cannabis
interactions.details: Large amounts of cannabis may cause strong and somewhat unpredictable experiences in combination with MDMA. Cannabis should be saved for towards the end of the experience if possible.

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure  but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of  this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

drugs.summary: The world's most popular empathogen with powerful pro-social effects. Has been strongly linked to cognitive decline in excess. Popular at parties, it is often sold in powder or in pills, and may be adulterated with other similar chemicals.
drugs.name: MDMA

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes

NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

drugs.summary: An entactogen, stimulant and psychedelic first synthesised by Alexander Shulgin, MDOH is an analogue of MDA. Described as highly psychedelic, it is likely a serotonin releasing agent. It has not seen widespread use, perhaps due to a number of reported negative side effects such as urinary retention and a heavy comedown.
drugs.name: MDOH

drugs.summary: An obscure substituted methylenedioxyphenethylamine with practically no history of human use. Its pharmacological profile is largely unknown, but potentially exhibits similar properties to other MDxx compounds. May be a monoamine releaser, reuptake inhibitor or both.
drugs.name: MDPA

drugs.summary: MDPHP aka 'Monkey-Dust' is a substituted cathinone and pyrovalerone which has been sold as an alternative to a-PHP and MDPV. Said to be less intense than MDPV with similar effects. MDPHP potency is said to vary widely, and there are reports of mixed composition batches containing other drugs. Very little is known about MDPHP in terms of toxicity, pharmacology and metabolism.

effects: stimulation (mental and physical), euphoria, increased mental clarity, elevated heart rate, headache, confusion, paranoia, loss of apetite, muscle tension
drugs.summary: MDPV is a potent, and extremely compulsive synthetic euphoric stimulant, which shares some empathogenic effects with MDMA. Has a reputation for causing psychosis. MDPV has been found in products sold as "bath salts", "plant food/fertilizer", and in some "ecstasy."
drugs.name: MDPV

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: A short acting analogue of Methaqualone, that is much more potent.
drugs.name: Mebroqualone

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. Vomit aspiration a risk when passed out, lay down in recovery position if ingested.

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Small doses of benzos can end a bad trip, but both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and this can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely

drugs.summary: Benzodiazepine derivative that has all of the classic benzodiazepine effects. Is a long-acting benzodiazepine drug (Half life of 36-200 hours) Is rarely prescribed in most countries. Is also a prodrug for Diazepam. Think of it as Desoxy-Diazepam if you'd like to.
drugs.name: Medazepam

drugs.summary: A naturally occurring hormone produced in the body, which promotes sleep at certain times in the day based on the circadian rhythm. It is also commonly available as a drug to treat insomnia and promote a proper sleep cycle. It can be used to promote sleepfulness at the tail-end of drug experiences, though it is not particularly hypnotic.
drugs.name: Melatonin

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A rare stimulant, psychedelic and amphetamine discovered by Alexander Shulgin. Related to the DOx class of drugs, little is known about this obscure compound's pharmacology, however it is likely to be potent and have a long duration.
drugs.name: MEM

drugs.summary: An NMDA-antagonist that if used recreationally can cause to a very prolonged "hole" lasting up to 16+ hours.
drugs.name: Memantine

interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

effects: Generally described as being more intense of a stimulant than MDMA but with somewhat less of an empathogenic feel.
drugs.summary: A shortlived euphoric stimulant, developed as an analogue of MDMA, which was extremely popular in the research chemical scene before being banned. Commonly seen on street markets but rarer online. Very strong urge to redose compulsively.

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A psychedelic of the phenethylamine family. Found in psychedelic cacti that have long been used by peoples native to the Southwestern US and Mexico, including Peyote and San Pedro cacti, among others. Can be found as cactus pulp, as an extract from cacti, or as a synthetic substance created in a lab.
drugs.name: Mescaline

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: A rare psychedelic tryptamine, related to DMT and DET. Little information exists about the effects or pharmacology of this drug.
drugs.name: MET

drugs.summary: A benzodiazepine derivative. Which is mostly an anxiolytic substance, without strong hypnotic properties that most benzodiazepines have. Its active metabolite is N-desmethylmetaclazepam, which is the main metabolite. Slightly more effective as an anxiolytic than Bromazepam.
drugs.name: Metaclazepam

drugs.summary: Muscle relaxant, that is used to relieve pain from general pain, and other musculoskeletal conditions.
drugs.name: Metaxalone

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

effects: increased energy/alertness, Decreased need for sleep, Increased sociability, mood lift, increase sexuality, Excessive talking, Decreased appetite, Weight loss, Sweating, Distrubed sleep patterns, Bruxia, Visual and audiotory hallucinations itchiness, agressiveness, moodiness, fatal kidney disorder, possible brain damage liver damage.
drugs.summary: A fairly common and very strong CNS stimulant. It is sometimes prescribed in the form of desoxyn for ADHD and severe obesity. In low doses, methamphetamine can elevate mood, increase alertness, concentration, energy and reduces appetite. At higher doses, it can induce mania, psychosis and muscle degeneration among other issues. Tolerant users may report much higher doses than new users.
drugs.name: Methamphetamine

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: A pharmaceutical depressant and sedative phased out due to the better safety profile of benzodiazepines, part of the Qualone group of substances. Now very rare, except in South Africa.
drugs.name: Methaqualone

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: BK-PMMA Closely related to PMMA and others. Stimulant.
drugs.name: Methedrone

drugs.summary: A dissociative from the diarylethylamine class, a more potent analogue of diphenidine. Known to be unpredictable, and can cause blackouts.
drugs.name: Methoxphenidine

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

drugs.summary: An arylcyclohexylamine drug and analogue of ketamine, though slightly less potent. Produces similar dissociative and anaesthetic effects. Very rare.

drugs.summary: Drug of the Piperazine class. The 4-Methoxy-Î±-keto analogue of Methylbenzylpiperazine. Seemingly inactive on its own. Was sold in tandem with Mephtetramine.

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

effects: Increased alertness, Euphoria, Increased motivation, Reduced appetite, Flushing of the face, Increased body temperature, Tachycardia (Increased heart rate) Paranoia, Insomnia.
drugs.summary: A psychostimulant commonly used in the treatment of ADHD, narcolepsy and obesity, particularly in the EU instead of Adderall. Methylphenidate is also a 5HT1A receptor agonist. Sometimes prescribed off-label to help the withdrawals from cocaine and other stimulants.
drugs.name: Methylphenidate

drugs.summary: Sedative of the pipeidinedone family. Was used for treating insomnia, yet is rarely used today due to substances with fewer side effects, such as benzodiazepines.
drugs.name: Methyprylon

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

drugs.summary: Also known as desmethyletizolam, a thienodiazepine similar in effects and structure to etizolam, but around half as potent and with around a 60% longer half-life. A sedative, and hypnotic, it may cause amnesia and lowered inhibitions in excess.
drugs.name: Metizolam

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: 5-Methoxytryptamine, a tryptamine derivative that naturally occurs in the body at low levels. No evidence of recreational use. Apparently enhances dreams.
drugs.name: Mexamine

drugs.summary: Benzodiazepine derivative that has been trialed for anxiety and was found to be effective for anxiety at one week week follow-ups yet after three weeks it had lost its therapeutic anxiolytic properties and becoming no more effective than placebo.

interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

drugs.summary: Mexedrone is a stimulant drug of the cathinone class. It alters the reuptake of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine to cause euphoria,  and is similar in effects to mephedrone. It is considered a designer drug and is in a legally grey area globally.
drugs.name: Mexedrone

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. Vomit aspiration a risk when passed out, lay down in recovery position if ingested.

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Small doses of benzos can end a bad trip, but both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and this can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely

effects: Anxiolytic, Sedative, Muscle Relaxant, Amnesia, Dystaxia, Hypnotic.
drugs.summary: A common hypnotic, sedative and anxiolytic benzodiazepine. High doses may cause amnesia and loss of inhibitions. Unusually, it is water soluble, and commonly used as a premedication for sedation as the solubility makes it better for IV use than other benzodiazepines.
drugs.name: Midazolam

effects: Euphoria, empathy, insight, brightened colour, Closed/Open eye visuals, enhanced tactile sensation, mental/physical stimulation, decreased appetite, pupil dilation, restlessness, change in perception, ego softening, sweating/chills, muscle tension, confusion, insomnia.
drugs.summary: N-Methyl-N-isopropyltryptamine, a tryptamine analogue of DMT, a very uncommon drug with very few reports of human use. Described as 'more psychedelic than hallucinogenic' users report only mild visuals with some stimulation and cognitive effects. One of the more stable tryptamines.
drugs.name: MiPT

drugs.summary: Dissociative research chemical similar to PCP, and Ketamine. Dizocilpine, also known as MK-801, is a non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor.
drugs.name: MK-801

drugs.summary: A reversible MAOI which is prescribed to treat depression and anxiety. Its reversibility and short-acting length of effects often means it is used in "pharmahuasca" preparations.
drugs.name: Moclobemide

interactions.name: 2C-x
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

interactions.name: Caffeine
interactions.details: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

interactions.name: NBOMes
interactions.details: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

interactions.name: 2C-T-x
interactions.details: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

interactions.name: 5-MeO-xxT
interactions.details: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.details: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: No additional Information

drugs.summary: A wakefulness promoting, long acting stimulant which is typically only used functionally, because there is no real euphoric component to its effects. Also prescribed for daytime sleeping disorders.
drugs.name: Modafinil

interactions.name: Ketamine
interactions.details: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: MXE
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: DXM
interactions.details: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

interactions.name: N2O
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

drugs.summary: A synthetic opioid drug that was rumoured to be roughly 80% the potency of Morphine orally. Was created by Dainippon Pharmaceutical in the 1970's. It has been used as a lead compound for the design of related substances. It has been associated with hearing loss and hair loss. Structurally unrelated to most other opioid drugs. Treat with caution, especially long term use.

effects: visual distortion, color enhancement, sense of connectedness with nature, sense of well being, sense of wonder
drugs.summary: Fungi containing psilocybin, a prototypical psychedelic with similar effects to LSD, but with a shorter duration; also considered as being more confusing, introspective and entheogenic. Usually refers to psilocybe mushrooms rather than Amanitas, which have different effects. Are considered physically safe if properly identified, which should always be done by an expert.
drugs.name: Mushrooms

interactions.name: Î±MT
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: Alcohol
interactions.details: There is a high risk of memory loss, vomiting and severe ataxia from this combination.

interactions.name: GHB/GBL
interactions.details: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the patient falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

interactions.name: Opioids
interactions.details: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

interactions.name: Tramadol
interactions.details: No additional Information

interactions.name: DOx
interactions.details: As an NMDA antagonist MXE potentiates DOx which can be unpleasantly intense

interactions.name: NBOMes

interactions.name: 2C-T-x

interactions.name: PCP
interactions.details: There are no reports available about this combination

interactions.name: Amphetamines
interactions.details: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

interactions.name: MDMA
interactions.details: There have been reports of risky serotonergic interactions when the two are taken at the same time, but MXE taken to the end of an MDMA experience does not appear to cause the same issues.

interactions.name: Cocaine
interactions.details: Stimulants taken with MXE can lead to hypermanic states much more easily, especially if sleep is avoided.

interactions.name: Benzodiazepines
interactions.details: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess.

interactions.name: SSRIs
interactions.details: Depending on the SSRI this combination can be unpredictable

interactions.name: MAOIs
interactions.details: MAO-B inhibitors appear to increase the potency of MXE. MAO-A inhbitors have some negative reports associated with the combination but there isn't much information available
